ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Developed a firm grasp on the tenses learned in L1 and L2 as well as the future tense, an expanded vocabulary, and greater fluency in speaking.
Spanish
I really refreshed and grew my ability to speak and write Spanish.
I develop a better understanding of how to comprehend a language holistically, by ensuring my skills in speaking, listening, writing and grammar all  were maintained and at a similar level.
I improved my ability to speak, write, and understand Spanish.
I learned some vocabulary and reinforced grammar that I had already learned.
I improved my reading, writing, listening and speaking skills in Spanish.
Learned how to write, read and speak more fluidly in Spanish and refined knowledge in past, future, and subjunctive tenses in Spanish.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A strength of this course is how quickly it moves. With the material being learned, it makes the most sense to move rapidly through the material. A weakness of the class was that the two teachers were not able to co-teach a class. I think that couldve gotten them on the same page as to where the class was at.
I think it is very difficult to learn a language remotely. I think we did the best we could under the circumstances.

The course was very well organized and the teachers made our responsibilities for the class very clear. One weakness would be the amount that we spoke the language, as I felt my writing and grammar skills were a bit stronger than my listening comprehension and speaking skills.

I thought the course was conducted really well, and I appreciated having Wednesdays as a break from Zoom. There were some points during the semester where expectations were unclear, but that got resolved pretty quickly. Both professors were really kind and understanding, and they both made efforts to ensure that we enjoyed the class. I didn't expect to enjoy the breakout rooms, but they were actually a nice way to get to know other people in the class, and they made the 2 hour class period go by pretty quickly. I really liked the balance between class discussions and in-class practice of grammatical structures. Overall, if you're willing to put in the time, the class is really great. Even though it was intensive due to it being compressed into 5 weeks, I felt like it was still pretty manageable.
I think a great strength of this course was the amount of conversation we engaged in. I think the main project could be improved. I've basically done the exact same project 3 terms in a row.
The course covered so much material in such a short amount of time and sometimes it felt as though there was inadequate time to learn some of the material or it wasn't explained enough in class.

Strengths:
Constant activities to work on improving speaking, reading, and writing abilities
Professors

Weaknesses:
Over Zoom

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes absolutely. Summer is a great time for a language credit especially if youre able to just take one class. As languages are usually some of the more requiring classes, taking it in the summer is extremely beneficial.

Yes, I think that while the course was challenging and a bit of work, it was well organized and the environment definitely was focused on ensuring the student's skills were maintained and built upon throughout the course.
I would recommend YSS Spanish
Yes. If you are hoping to fulfill a language requirement, then this class is a good way to do it.
Yes. Doing Spanish over the summer was a great way to get a requirement out of the way, and it was actually pretty fun.
I like the summer class format of Spanish if it's the last level of the course that you have to take, but it feels a bit rushed and left me a bit shaky going into L4.
Yes, if you want to learn more Spanish this is the best course. The only way to get better is by practicing and receiving feedback from others who speak the language to  you
